item.title: After a Successful Year, Marvel Rivals Has Big Plans, Teases MCU-Related Content
item.content:encoded:
It's been a little over a year since NetEase released its hero shooter Marvel Rivals. Since then, the game has taken on a life of its own and become one of the most popular games of 2025. During The Game Awards 2025, TechRaptor sat down with the publishing and marketing lead of NetEase Games, Yachen Bian, and the executive producer of Marvel Games, Danny Koo, to talk about the game's journey and what they plan for the future--including a tease of potential content timed with Avengers: Doomsday.

One of the things that Marvel Rivals has been doing well is releasing content at a steady rate. Each season usually lasts about two months, and once a month, the team releases a new character based on the season's theme. As one might expect, the team already has an internal roadmap and plans out who they want in the game a year in advance. But it's also so much more than that. Koo explained that it also has to make sense narratively for them to join the game, too. 

Team-ups are such a core part of the game. In short, they give players special abilities when two or specific characters are both on the field at the same time. Not only are these team-ups fun to watch, but they can also make or break games depending on how you use them. Koo explained the reason for adding this was because it only seemed natural to have them, and when you look at any comic, you can see all sorts of team-ups, such as Deadpool & Wolverine, or any of the Avengers and X-Men. 

Even though certain team-ups like Venom x Spider-Man seem like a slam dunk, they won't be in the game forever. This is because the team wanted to "encourage fresh new mechanics every season." The fear is that if they keep one team-up in the game for too long, it'll become "stale," so they want to "inject new excitement every season." Although Koo didn't go into much detail, he explained that the team plans to "expand this system" in 2026. 

One thing worth mentioning is that earlier this year, Marvel Rivals announced that they would eventually be working on new original characters not from the comics, to join the game. Shortly after that, the team received pushback from the community on this. When asked if the team has an idea of when they would be implementing new original characters, Koo reassured me that this would be a last resort item they use when they run out of established Marvel Comic characters.

"At Marvel games, I've worked on several original characters, and that's [only] when we need to do it. With so many characters in the Marvel Universe, we want to make sure each hero feels distinct from each other," Koo explained. "That's why you don't see five similar Spider-Men swinging around. We're going to continue to make sure that the existing batch of heroes [joining the game] will be serving the community. Who knows, in the future, when there is a particular need that existing thousands of other heroes can't serve, then we'll think of something original. But at this point, we are not ready for that." 

It's no secret that the team at Marvel Rivals is known for drawing their characters in very specific ways that complement their bodies. You don't have to look too hard to find examples of this (I'm looking at you, Daredevil and Emma Frost). During our talk, I brought up the famous Pedro Pascal video where he first saw the Invisible Woman Malice skin. It's clear that the team adopted their own art style that appeals to both the male and female gaze. Koo explained that the idea was to always be tasteful yet realistic.

"Being a superhero [is very physical], they have a certain body archetype. So, of course, players will gravitate and be shocked by it. But if you look at the history of comics, it's always [shown off various body types]. You always see those physics, and the costumes highlight the physics," Koo explained. "Also, we're not afraid to show that off while not going too far, because this is still a T-rated game. We're not going into uncharted territory; we don't want [our game] to be adult stuff." 

Koo also made it a point to address that some of the skins they have are a lot tamer than their original counterparts. He used Malice as an example and explained how the original costume was more revealing than the one people see in Marvel Rivals, so the team wanted to "modernize it." The new Malice look was so popular that Marvel Comics decided to bring it back in a new series that is launching this month. 

As the team looks ahead to 2026, Koo explained that "2025 was a great year, but we have bigger plans for 2026." This includes a steady stream of heroes to join the roster as well as a new PVE (Players Versus Environment) mode. 

"[Our] PVE mode, Marvel Zombies, jived well with players, so we're gonna expand upon that. We're also going to expand upon the hero power fantasy and the team-ups," Koo says. "So you're gonna see more efforts towards that area to fulfill a player's fantasy of playing superheroes in the Marvel Rivals universe. And, of course, next year, we have on the Marvel [Studio] side, two big movies coming out. We're also going to collab on that front in a huge way." 

One thing the Marvel Rivals team has been very vocal about is how successful the PVE Marvel Zombies mode has been. During our interview, Koo alluded that this might be a mode players will see again this time next year, and we aim to look at it more deeply to further expand the gameplay. But the team is also looking to experiment with other non-traditional PVE modes, like what we saw with the Ultron chess mode. 

The team declined to confirm whether an upcoming PVE mode would tie into the upcoming MCU film Avengers: Doomsday, but they assured me they have a release date in mind for the next mode. That said, they did also tease that when Avengers: Doomsday comes out next year, certain story beats would be concluded in Marvel Rivals. 

It's no secret that Marvel Rivals took a lot of inspiration from other games in the space, like Overwatch 2. It wouldn't be far-fetched to compare the two games because they look and play so similarly. Koo went on to say that the team is a massive fan of shooters in general and tends to gravitate toward games like Overwatch and Counter-Strike. Before Marvel Rivals was even greenlit, they often toyed with the idea of making a hero shooter. 

"[NetEase] looked at all the available games out in the market and saw that there was really no superhero shooter. [So we thought] we're going to do it our own way, the Marvel way." 

A large part of why the team has had great success is how it communicates with its fanbase. Whenever changes happen that the majority of players disagree with, they're quick to fix them, and on top of that, the team is super on the nose with the memes and jokes surrounding the game, even leaning into them. Koo attributed a large part of that to the game's Discord server, which is the largest in the world with almost 4.2 million members. 

"We have an army of content creators and moderators who compile feedback and suggestions. It also helps that I'm on social media and I get pinged left and right with people saying, 'Hey, this is interesting.' Or complaints about game features and bugs. So we see all of that stuff, including the dev team," Koo said. "It's not like we're putting up a wall. We literally tore the wall down and said, 'Hey, say whatever you want. We're listening, and we're doing our best to find out what the issue or interest is.'" 

This was something that Bian went on to echo, by explaining that the team doesn't necessarily have a department that surfs the web to see what people are saying. So whenever you see someone like Creative Director Guangyun Chen say something as silly as "Aura Walk" in a community update video, it's them being genuine about it. Koo admitted that sometimes they'll see something the community is asking about online and text Chen to see if it's something they can implement in the game. 

It's clear that the Marvel Rivals team has many ideas in store for 2026. After our long conversation, I'm confident that the team can deliver on another successful year as they enter year two. If you haven't tried it yet, Marvel Rivals is a free-to-play game available on PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, PC, and Xbox Series X|S.

Luis Gutierrez is a journalist who's worked with various outlets, including IGN, GameSpot, Kotaku, and many more. He has a degree in journalism and loves… More about Luis



https://techraptor.net/gaming/features/one-year-into-marvel-rivals-team-ups-tasteful-design-and-community-driven-1

item.title: Terminator: Survivors Delayed Indefinitely, Multiplayer Canceled
item.content:encoded:
Developer and publisher Nacon has revealed that post-apocalyptic survival game Terminator: Survivors has been delayed beyond its initial 2025 release window, and that a key feature has been canceled as well.

In a news post on Steam, Nacon says Terminator: Survivors, which was originally due to launch in Early Access sometime this year (having already been delayed once), "won't be launching in 2025", and that the studio doesn't have a new release date "locked in" yet either.

However, there is a small (potential) silver lining to this news; Nacon says that it's adjusting its release plans because it no longer wants to launch Terminator: Survivors in Early Access, so when the game does arrive, it'll be a "complete and polished experience", per the studio.

Additionally, Nacon says it's canning the co-op multiplayer aspect of Terminator: Survivors, having come to the conclusion that a single-player title would be better for delivering an "authentic Terminator experience".

Nacon says that although Terminator: Survivors won't be launching in 2025, the studio will be holding a number of closed playtests under a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) "as the launch window gets closer". If you want to sign up for those tests, you can do so here.

If you're unfamiliar with Terminator: Survivors, it is, as the name suggests, a survival game based on the Terminator series of movies (and ancillary media, of course).

Originally revealed last year, Terminator: Survivors takes place four years after Judgment Day, the event that devastated humanity and saw the machines rising up to rule the world. You'll need to battle Skynet's prototypes and help the Resistance claim a new future for mankind.

We no longer know exactly when to expect Terminator: Survivors, but if you want to keep up with Nacon's progress on the game, then you can wishlist it on PC via Steam right here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: November US Sales Data Shows Call of Duty Still Riding High
item.content:encoded:
Reports of Call of Duty's demise are greatly exaggerated, at least if Circana's latest US gaming sales data roundup is to be believed; the latest game in the long-running shooter series still reigns supreme.

According to the firm's ever-reliable Mat Piscatella, Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 still managed to top the all-format premium sales chart for November, beating out rivals like Battlefield 6, Pokemon Legends: Z-A, and Ghost of Yotei (all of which, admittedly, originally launched in October).

Battlefield 6 is in second place for the month, with annual sports releases NBA 2K26, Madden NFL 26, and EA Sports FC 26 taking up third, fourth, and fifth place respectively. Pokemon and Ghost of Yotei are in sixth and seventh before another sports game, EA Sports College Football 26, snags eighth.

Rounding out the top ten for the month are Minecraft, which can always be seen pretty close to the top few places in the chart, and Kirby Air Riders.

Despite Black Ops 7's strong performance in November's chart, it hasn't managed to topple Battlefield 6 in the year-to-date stakes; in fact, it's currently sitting at a rather measly seventh on that chart, having been beaten out by the likes of Monster Hunter Wilds and NBA 2K26.

It's worth saying that Black Ops 7 is at something of a disadvantage here given that all of its rivals have had several months to rack up sales, but given that Call of Duty is usually a sales behemoth, this probably won't be particularly encouraging for Activision.

Indeed, the publisher recently revealed that back-to-back yearly releases of Modern Warfare and Black Ops games will end, presumably paving the way for another sub-series to break up the repetition a little.

It's well worth taking a look at Piscatella's full thread for some more nerdy statistical breakdowns of how the gaming industry did sales-wise in November. Stay tuned for December's figures!

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph



https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/circana-november-2025-call-of-duty

item.title: Dispatch Apparently Coming to Switch 2 and Switch in January
item.content:encoded:
A listing for adventure game-slash-management sim Dispatch has been spotted on the Nintendo eShop, suggesting that the game may be coming to both Switch 2 and Switch next month.

As spotted by Gematsu, an Australian eShop listing for Dispatch appears to point to a release date of January 29th for the game on both of Nintendo's consoles. It'll have an install size of 13.6GB on both machines and will also offer a free Switch 2 upgrade path for original Switch owners.

It is, of course, possible that the January 29th date is a placeholder, but it's an oddly specific one if so, given that the date in question is only just over a month away. I'd say it's a safe bet AdHoc Studio's game will be arriving on Switch 2 and Switch soon.

If you're not familiar with Dispatch, it's an adventure game created by AdHoc Studio, a developer that boasts several ex-Telltale staffers among its ranks.

As you might expect from folks who worked on Telltale's games, Dispatch is primarily an episodic choice-based adventure in which you'll make a series of decisions that will impact the game's narrative as it progresses.

However, the game also features a management element in which you must serve as a dispatcher, sending heroes to tackle crimes across the city. The decisions you make during the narrative segments may also end up impacting what you can do while you're dispatching.

Released earlier this year, Dispatch managed to cross a million sales in just ten days, going on to pass the two million mark less than two weeks later. It's safe to say there's a voracious appetite for this one.

Dispatch is available right now on PC and PlayStation 5, and if this report is correct, then it's due to launch on Switch 2 and Switch in January as well. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph



https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/dispatch-switch-2-switch-eshop-listing

item.title: Forza Motorsport Updates to End as Focus Shifts to Forza Horizon 6
item.content:encoded:
Developer Turn 10 Studios has announced that regular Forza Motorsport updates will end as the team's focus shifts towards the upcoming Forza Horizon 6.

In a blog post on the official Forza website, Turn 10 says that as it prepares for the new installment in the simcade racing sub-series, which is due to land next year, it does not "plan to introduce new cars, tracks, features, or regular bug fixes for Forza Motorsport" anymore.

Despite this, the servers for Forza Motorsport will remain active, and Turn 10 will continue to host "special events and competitions" within the game, as well as "reintroducing previously released Featured Tours and reward cars on a monthly basis". If you're hoping for anything more substantial than that, though, you're out of luck.

While previous games in the Forza Horizon series have been developed by Playground Games, Forza Horizon 6 will be a co-production between that studio and Turn 10, which is presumably why the latter can't give any more attention to Forza Motorsport.

If you need a reminder, the latest Forza Motorsport game, which simply bears the name of its series and no accompanying number, was first revealed back in 2020.

Unlike Forza Horizon, the Motorsport series (from which Horizon is a spinoff) emphasizes elements like customization and realism; it places a much heavier emphasis on the "simulation" part of the series' equation.

The latest game was released in 2023 to a generally positive reception, although our own reviewer Blair was decidedly more lukewarm towards it, criticizing its lack of aesthetic sensibilities and its "uninvolving" and "uncreative" gameplay.

As part of a sweeping wave of layoffs at Microsoft earlier this year, a number of Turn 10 Studios employees were reportedly let go, so it's also possible that the developer simply doesn't have the staff count to support Forza Motorsport anymore.

At any rate, although updates will no longer be released for Forza Motorsport, you can grab the game right now on PC and Xbox Series X|S if you'd like.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph



https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/forza-motorsport-updates-ending
